item.description:
Have you noticed that TVs don't have brightness controls anymore. It sucks -- it's hard to watch during the day.

Now I'm using my Lenovo Chromebook outdoors at a Starbucks. Can't find anyway to increase brightness. Very hard to read the screen.
item.source:markdown:
Have you noticed that TVs don't have brightness controls anymore. It sucks -- it's hard to watch during the day.
Now I'm using my Lenovo Chromebook outdoors at a Starbucks. Can't find anyway to increase brightness. Very hard to read the screen.

item.description:
@mczoodt It's intentional.

It's the title of the thread.

My RSS reader will interpret it as the title of the post that it generates from the thread.

item.title: Was 2-factor such a good idea?
item.description:
Now that all our services use our phones to allow us to connect to our accounts, what happens if you lose your phone? I don't mean just the physical phone, what if you lose control of the number? It can happen.

I'm thinking of switching carriers, but do I dare? What if the number gets lost in the transition. All of a sudden I can't get to anything.
item.source:markdown:
Now that all our services use our phones to allow us to connect to our accounts, what happens if you lose your phone? I don't mean just the physical phone, what if you lose control of the number? It can happen.
I'm thinking of switching carriers, but do I dare? What if the number gets lost in the transition. All of a sudden I can't get to anything.

item.title: Two-way RSS
item.description:
I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.

As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like Substack only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.

But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.

Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.

Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious. I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.
item.source:markdown:
I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.
As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like [Substack](https://t.co/MCOiYl6ihr) only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious. I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.
